summary: The study compared nineteen commercial lipases for their ability to hydrolyze phosphatidylcholine in a reverse micellar system, finding that lipases from Mucor or Rhizopus species showed high reactivity while those from Aspergillus and Humicola sp. exhibited little activity.
key_claims: Lipases from Mucor or Rhizopus species showed high reactivity in hydrolyzing phosphatidylcholine.
Lipases from Aspergillus and Humicola sp. exhibited low reactivity.

reaction_types.name: hydrolysis
reaction_types.context: of phosphatidylcholine in a reverse micellar system

reactor.name: reaction mixture
reactor.value: 5 mL isooctane, 50 mg PC and AOT

_title: Comparative study of commercially available lipases in hydrolysis reaction of phosphatidylcholine
_abstract: Nineteen commercial lipase preparations were compared with respect to their ability to hydrolyze phosphatidylcholine (PC) in a reverse micellar system. In terms of the source organism, lipases from Mucor or Rhizopus species showed comparatively high reactivity, while those from Aspergillus and Humicola sp. exhibited little PC hydrolysis activity. Almost no hydrolysis reaction was observed by positionally nonspecific lipases derived from Candida sp. The results suggest that particular attention should be paid to the source organism in selecting lipases for use in the enzymatic conversion of phospholipids.
